braided: Pattern of overlapping and underlapping hair
Typically uniform thickness throughout each braid
Can be of varying lengths, often extending from the scalp
May have decorative elements like beads or ribbons
Can form various styles, such as single braids, pigtails, or cornrows
bubbly: clear or colored liquid with bubbles
effervescent appearance with tiny bubbles rising to the surface
served in a glass or clear bottle
often in a flute, wine glass, or tumbler
can have a bottle with a cork and foil seal (for sparkling wine)
condensation on the glass or bottle (indicating it's cold)
may have a label indicating champagne, prosecco, or another type of sparkling drink
chequered: alternating blocks of two or more contrasting colors, typically black and white
squares or rectangles arranged in a grid
consistent alignment and spacing of blocks
flat, uniform appearance across a surface
cracked: Break or fissure in a surface
Contrast in color or texture along the crack line
Varying widths along the length of the crack
Disruption in the continuity of the material (such as glass, pavement, or walls)
Possible radiating patterns, especially in glass
Shadowing or depth indicating separation of materials
Chipped or fragmented edges around the crack
crosshatched: lines often vary in thickness and spacing
used to create shading and texture
appears in illustrations, drawings, and etchings
often seen in monochrome or black-and-white images
crystalline: various colors or can be colorless
reflective surfaces that sparkle or glisten
faceted surfaces from natural growth or human cutting
dotted: Dots that are uniform in size
High contrast between the dots and the background
Typically, dots can be of various colors
Commonly found on fabrics, wallpapers, or designs
flecked: Presence of small, irregular spots or patches
Spots or patches are often scattered or sprinkled
Variations in color, typically against a different background color
Can be found on various surfaces or materials (e.g., fabric, animal fur, painted surfaces)
May create a speckled or dappled effect
freckled: Small, irregularly-shaped spots on the skin
Spots that are slightly darker than the surrounding skin
Commonly found on areas exposed to sunlight, such as the face, shoulders, and arms
Can vary in color, often light to medium brown
May appear in clusters or scattered patterns
Generally more prominent on fair-skinned individuals
frilly: typically associated with feminine or ornamental styles
can be in a variety of colors and patterns
gauzy: Often has a soft, flowing texture
May have a slight sheen or shimmer
Edges may appear delicate or frayed
Often used for curtains, veils, or delicate garments
grid: A pattern of intersecting vertical and horizontal lines
Uniformly spaced intersections forming a series of squares or rectangles
Can be made of various materials like metal, wood, or drawn/printed on a surface
Often used in backgrounds, architectural elements, or graphics
The lines can be solid, dashed, or dotted
grooved: Linear indentation or depression on a surface
May appear as a series of ridges and furrows
Can be found on various materials like metal, wood, or plastic
Often used to create traction or fit with another component
Can vary in depth and width
May appear on the side or edge of an object
interlaced: Visible horizontal lines or scan lines on the screen (especially when viewing fast-moving images or in freeze frames)
Image artifacts such as screen tearing or combing effects in motion sequences
Lower overall image quality when compared to progressive scan displays
Traditional (CRT) television or early LCD/LED screens more likely to use interlacing
knitted: Visible stitches like knit or purl
Can be in the form of garments (like sweaters, scarves, hats)
Often features ribbing or cable patterns
lacelike: often features repeating motifs such as flowers, leaves, or geometric designs
open, see-through areas created by the pattern
typically found in fabric or clothing items like doilies, tablecloths, dresses, or curtains
may appear in white or various colors, typically in a more delicate material like thread or yarn
textures that appear fine and detailed
lined: males have a prominent mane around the head
females do not have a mane
a tuft of hair at the end of the tail
meshed: Pattern of small, often uniform, openings or gaps
Material that may be metallic, plastic, or textile
Typically appears in items like screens, fences, or netting
Often used for filtration, separation, or as a barrier
paisley: Found on fabrics, wallpapers, and other decorative surfaces
May include both floral and abstract elements
perforated: Presence of small, evenly spaced holes
The holes may form a line or pattern
Typically found on the edge of paper or certain materials
Designed to be easily torn along the line of holes
polka-dotted: the dots can be in contrasting colors to the background
appears on surfaces such as fabric, clothing, accessories, or decor
porous: surfaces with tiny holes or pores
texture that appears rough or sponge-like
varied in appearance, could be organic like a sponge or synthetic like a foam
can appear in numerous colors depending on the material
potholed: Depression or hole on a road surface
Typically found on asphalt or concrete roads
May vary in size from small indentations to large craters
smeared: can be any color, often different from the background
varies in transparency, with some parts more opaque than others
may appear on various surfaces such as glass, fabric, or paper
often disrupts clear visibility of the underlying image or surface
spiralled: Winding or coiling around a central point
Varying widths and distances between the coils
May appear in natural forms (e.g., shells, galaxies) or man-made objects (e.g., spiral staircases)
stained: Area of discoloration on a surface
Color that contrasts with the surrounding area
May appear wet, dry, or set into the material
Often found on fabric, walls, floors, or furniture
stratified: varying colors or textures between the layers
a change in material composition from one layer to another
clear demarcation lines separating each layer
studded: consistent pattern or random placement of studs
studs may be round, rectangular, or uniquely shaped
often seen on leather or denim materials
commonly found on belts, jackets, shoes, or bags
shiny or reflective surfaces on studs
may be accompanied by other embellishments such as embroidery or patches
typically made of wood or metal
evenly spaced in walls (usually 16 or 24 inches apart)
may have electrical wires or plumbing running through them (if wall is open)
part of the interior structure of walls, covered by drywall or other wall materials
waffled: grid-like pattern with square or rectangular wells
often accompanied by toppings like syrup, butter, fruits
woven: Often found in the form of textiles, baskets, or mats
Varied colors based on the materials used
May have frayed edges or visible knots
Can range from simple to complex designs
The appearance of being handcrafted or machine-made
wrinkled: variations in light and shadow due to texture differences
typically associated with materials like fabric, skin, or paper
zigzagged: repeated pattern of connected diagonal lines
lines changing direction at a consistent interval
typically forms a series of V shapes or inverted V shapes
can be found in various contexts such as fabric patterns, road markings, or natural formations
